Documentation.name: UML Profile for GML Application Schemas
Documentation.notes: This profile defines a set of stereotypes and tagged values for defining XSD Schemas that follow the patterns used in XSD representations of GML Application Schemas. Stereotype.name: Application Schema
Stereotype.notes: Root of model describing an Application Schema. Contains definitions of feature-types and other components related to a single conceptually coherent application. This will normally have a single maintenance and governance framework, and shall use a single XML namespace.

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: owner
Tag.description: Party responsible for maintenance of this package

Tag.name: targetNamespace
Tag.description: URI to unique target namespace

Tag.name: xmlns
Tag.description: Prefix associated with namespace

Tag.name: version
Tag.description: Schema version

Tag.name: xsdDocument
Tag.description: Relative path to XML Schema document corresponding to this package.

Stereotype.name: Leaf
Stereotype.notes: Subset of model describing a schema. A leaf package shall not contain any other packages. When implemented using W3C XML Schema, all Leaf package contents or component classes are typically placed within one XML schema document.

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: version
Tag.description: Schema version

Tag.name: xsdDocument
Tag.description: Relative path to XML Schema document corresponding to this package.

Stereotype.name: DataType
Stereotype.notes: Class represents a DataType as defined in ISO 19103, 19109, 19136. This includes structured classes without identity. In a GML implementation this is implemented as a complexType element in which the attributes and associations are complexContent (sub-elements) but the type is *not* derived (transitively) from AbstractGMLType or AbstractFeatureType. This should be used as the fall-through stereotype for classes in application schemas, to be used for all classes that do not fall into one of the other categories.

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: noPropertyType
Tag.description: suppress automatic creation of *PropertyType complexType

Tag.name: byValuePropertyType
Tag.description: enforce the 'by value' property pattern without xlinks

Stereotype.name: Type
Stereotype.notes: Class represents a type 'with identity' as defined in ISO 19118 and 19136. This is the default stereotype for classes in Application Schemas, i.e. a class with no stereotype is assumed to be a Type.

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: noPropertyType
Tag.description: suppress automatic creation of *PropertyType complexType

Tag.name: byValuePropertyType
Tag.description: enforce the 'by value' property pattern without xlinks

Stereotype.name: Enumeration
Stereotype.notes: Class represents an Enumeration as defined in ISO 19103, 19136 i.e. a fixed list of literal values, that are implemented in an XML Schema as enumeration restriction of xsd:string

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Stereotype.name: CodeList
Stereotype.notes: Class represents an CodeList as defined in ISO 19103, 19136; i.e. a list of consecutive integers or index values, which correspond to literal values as indicated in the schema annotation A key functional distinction compared to Enumeration is that CodeList is extensible. In the GML implementation this is normally accomplished through a union with a pattern defining a string 'other:value' where 'value' is a string without internal spaces

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: asDictionary
Tag.description: implement as a dictionary instead of enumeration

Stereotype.name: BasicType
Stereotype.notes: Class represents a basic type as defined in ISO 19118, having a 'canonical' encoding. In the GML implementation, all UML attributes added in the derivation are implemented as XML attributes

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: xmlSchemaType
Tag.description: QName identifying the name of the XML Schema Type implementing this class

Stereotype.name: ListType
Stereotype.notes: Class definition where the representation is a list of primitive types from the implementation In the GML implementation, this is implemented by mapping to a W3C XML Schema builtin simpleType when possible, or a simpleContent type with a 'canonical' encoding

Tag.name: documentation
Tag.description: Normative documentation association with this element

Tag.name: item
Tag.description: Primitive type comprising list items
